results.title: A Warehouse for bodies
results.creator_credit: Allan Goldstein, Andy Thomson and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Life inside a prison in Canada, the Kingston Maximum Security Penitentiary, as seen by the guards and the inmates. Interviews with prisoners and guards paint a harsh picture. The day is punctuated with the sound of metal, and violence runs dangerously close to the surface. A useful film that explains the high degree of recidivism in a sub-culture that operates by a code of its own.

results.title: A War story
results.creator_credit: Anne Wheeler and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: How little a list of casualties tells the real story of war. Based on the diaries of Canadian doctor Ben Wheeler during his internment in a Japanese prisoner-of-war camp during World War II, this feature docudrama is not a “war story” in the conventional sense of strategy and battles, but rather a glowing account of the spirit and its will to survive physical and mental suffering. Newsreel footage of the fall of Singapore (where Major Wheeler was captured) has been interwoven with dramatic reconstructions of scenes inside the mining camp. An important aspect of this docudrama is that it is seen through the eyes of Ben Wheeler’s daughter as she interviews, in a very moving way, survivors of the camps. (Awards: Edmonton; New York; Ghent.) Cast: Doug Bagot, Rodrigue Deschenes, David Edney, W. Forrest MacDonald, Cecil Grinstead, Doug Kier, Patrick McGuigan, Allan Stebbings, Dean Stoker, Frank Turner, Gerry Whelpton, Tom Whitton.

results.title: A Waltz through the hills
results.creator_credit: Frank Arnold, Paul D. Barron, Roz Berrystone and Barron Films
results.brief_description: Based on the novel by G.M. Glaskin, this multi-award winning adventure is about two young children who, after their mother dies, decide to run-away to England to stay with their only surviving relatives to avoid being put in separate orphanages. The first stage of the journey involves walking 107 kilometres from an inland West Australian wheat belt town to perth. They are befriended by a young aboriginal man and his family, survive a bush-fire, eat off the land and eventually reach Perth to media and public acclaim.

results.title: A Very British coup
results.creator_credit: Ann Skinner, Sally Hibbin and Mick Jackson
results.brief_description: This is an absorbing political fable for the 90’s. Its a pacy thriller about an attempt to destabilise a fictitious British government. Harry Hopkins is an ex-steel worker from Sheffield who wins a General Election and becomes Prime Minister on a manifesto committed to radical policies. he is a man of the people who has a way with one-liners which fool the press but not the Opposition. Once inside Number 10, Harry enters a world of political intrigue and comes face to face with the media, the Civil Service, the armed forces, his own party and the Opposition. As each problem arises, Harry solves them in his own inimitable style. Cast: Ray McAnally, Alan MacNaughtan, Keith Allen.

results.title: A Union free seminar
results.creator_credit: Laszlo Barna, Laura Alper, Barrie Howells, Mark Zannis and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Techniques for union-proofing the workplace are presented in a concise, straightforward manner by Charles Hughes, management consultant and guru of the North American union-free movement. Excerpted from one of his popular management seminars, this film, and the information Hughes presents in it, will draw the attention of both union organizers and management.

results.title: A Telephone call for Genevieve Snow
results.creator_credit: Peter Long, Beth Frey and Blackout Productions
results.brief_description: Genevieve Snow (Beth Buchanan) is a mousey piano teacher at a primary school ruled by a formidable headmistress, in this revisionist version of the Little Red Riding Hood fairytale based on a short story by Carmel Bird. One day as he is driving past the school, Nigel hears Genevieve being summoned over the public address system and decides to call her and through the series of elliptical phone conversations that follow, the pair strike up a strange relationship. Yet Genevieve’s lonely desperation and Nigel’s odd canine obsessions suggests their mutual attraction may have fatal consequences. Moody black and white photography emphasises these sinister undertones, yet the gothic atmosphere of this seemingly cautionary tale is shot through with a sense of the absurd, especially in relation to the claustrophobic rituals that enforce conventional roles. Cast also includes Damien Richardson, Esme Melville. Awards: Silver Lion for best short film in competition 57th Venice Film Festival 2000.

results.title: A taste of Hong Kong (Captioned)
results.brief_description: This video, which has detailed demonstrations of traditional Chinese dishes and garnishes, is interspersed with views of life in Hong Kong, particularly the markets, the restaurants and the harbour. It is divided into five sections: “Delights of the heart” which covers breakfasts and dim sum, “Treasures from the sea”, “Meat roasts”, “Food and festivals” and “Homecooking”. Demonstrated dishes include spare ribs en papillotte, sauteed oysters with spring onion and ginger, roast pork and duck and spiced crispy chicken.

results.title: A Trip down memory lane
results.creator_credit: Arthur Lipsett, Donald Brittain and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Arthur Lipsett’s incisive look at human might, majesty and mayhem, compiled from some peculiar newsreel items of the twentieth century. The filmmaker calls this ‘additional material for a time capsule’, but his arrangement of pictures combined with Ron Alexander’s soundtrack makes it almost explosive. There are hundreds of items, once front-page news, but all wryly grotesque when seen in this reshuffle of the past. (Awards: San Francisco, Venice)
